Authors:
Thomas Silberfeld, Jessica W. Leigh, Heroen Verbruggen,
Corinne Cruaud, Bruno de Reviers, Florence Rousseau
Title:
A multi-locus time-calibrated phylogeny of the brown algae
(Heterokonta, Phaeophyceae): investigating the evolutionary nature of
the “Brown Algal Crown Radiation”
Keywords:
Phaeophyceae, brown algal crown radiation, non-molecular
characters evolution, multi-marker phylogeny, time-calibrated phylogeny,
bayesian relaxed molecular clock, hard/soft polytomy
Abstract:
The most conspicuous feature in the phaeophycean phylogeny
is a vast polytomy, named “brown algal crown radiation” (BACR),
encompassing 10+ out of 17 currently recognized brown algal orders.
Lately a resolution of the BACR has been initiated, therefore suggesting
that the so-called radiation may actually be an artefact due to the use
of quantitatively and/or qualitatively insufficient molecular markers.
Nevertheless (i) the resolution of the BACR remained incomplete and
ambiguous, and (ii) further exploration of the apparent polytomic nature
of the BACR is still lacking. The present work aims to address these
issues using a dual approach. First, a multi-marker phylogeny of the
brown algae was built from ten mitochondrial, plastid and nuclear loci
(>10,000 nt) of 72 phaeophycean taxa. Our phylogeny confirms the
phylogenetic insights uncovered by previous studies and increases
inter-ordinal resolution within the BACR. Non-molecular characters
classically used in ordinal delimitation were mapped on the molecular
topology to study their evolutionary history. Bayesian relaxed molecular
clock analysis was carried out to better characterize the nature of the
BACR and results in the first extensively sampled, time-calibrated
phaeophycean phylogeny to be published. The analysis shows that the BACR
is likely to be a soft polytomy encompassing an episode of
diversification spanning most of the Lower Cretaceous.
